an8.13:1.1.pli: “Aṭṭhahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato rañño bhaddo assājānīyo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an8.13:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a fine royal thoroughbred with eight factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and reckoned a factor of kingship.

an8.13:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño bhaddo assājānīyo ubhato sujāto hoti—
an8.13:1.3.eng: It’s when a fine royal thoroughbred is well born on both

an8.13:1.4.eng: the mother’s and the father’s sides.

an8.13:1.5.pli: Yassaṃ disāyaṃ aññepi bhaddā assājānīyā jāyanti, tassaṃ disāyaṃ jāto hoti.
an8.13:1.5.eng: He’s bred in the region fine thoroughbreds come from.

an8.13:1.8.eng: he eats carefully, without making a mess.

an8.13:1.9.pli: Jegucchī hoti uccāraṃ vā passāvaṃ vā abhinisīdituṃ vā abhinipajjituṃ vā.
an8.13:1.9.eng: He’s disgusted by sitting or lying down in excrement or urine.

an8.13:1.10.pli: Sorato hoti sukhasaṃvāso, na ca aññe asse ubbejetā.
an8.13:1.10.eng: He’s gentle and pleasant to live with, and he doesn’t upset the other horses.

an8.13:1.11.pli: Yāni kho panassa honti sāṭheyyāni kūṭeyyāni jimheyyāni vaṅkeyyāni, tāni yathābhūtaṃ sārathissa āvikattā hoti.
an8.13:1.11.eng: He openly shows his tricks, bluffs, ruses, and feints to his trainer,

an8.13:1.12.eng: so the trainer can try to subdue them.

an8.13:1.14.pli: ‘Kāmaññe assā vahantu vā mā vā, ahamettha vahissāmī’ti cittaṃ uppādeti.
an8.13:1.14.eng: ‘Whether or not the other horses carry their loads, I’ll carry mine.’

an8.13:1.15.eng: He always walks in a straight path.

an8.13:1.16.pli: Thāmavā hoti yāva jīvitamaraṇapariyādānā thāmaṃ upadaṃsetā.
an8.13:1.16.eng: He’s strong, and stays strong even until death.

an8.13:1.17.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahi aṅgehi samannāgato rañño bhaddo assājānīyo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.
an8.13:1.17.eng: A fine royal thoroughbred with these eight factors is worthy of a king. …

an8.13:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an8.13:2.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant with eight qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an8.13:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an8.13:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an8.13:2.7.eng: They’re disgusted with bad conduct by way of body, speech, or mind,

an8.13:2.8.pli: jegucchī hoti anekavihitānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ samāpattiyā.
an8.13:2.8.eng: and by attainment of the many kinds of unskillful things.

an8.13:2.9.pli: Sorato hoti sukhasaṃvāso, na aññe bhikkhū ubbejetā.
an8.13:2.9.eng: They're gentle and pleasant to live with, and they don’t upset the other mendicants.

an8.13:2.10.pli: Yāni kho panassa honti sāṭheyyāni kūṭeyyāni jimheyyāni vaṅkeyyāni, tāni yathābhūtaṃ āvikattā hoti satthari vā viññūsu vā sabrahmacārīsu.
an8.13:2.10.eng: They openly show their tricks, bluffs, ruses, and feints to their sensible spiritual companions,

an8.13:2.11.pli: Tesamassa satthā vā viññū vā sabrahmacārī abhinimmadanāya vāyamati.
an8.13:2.11.eng: so they can try to subdue them.

an8.13:2.13.pli: ‘Kāmaññe bhikkhū sikkhantu vā mā vā, ahamettha sikkhissāmī’ti cittaṃ uppādeti.
an8.13:2.13.eng: ‘Whether or not the other mendicants do their training, I’ll do mine.’

an8.13:2.14.eng: They always walk in a straight path.

an8.13:2.15.eng: And here the straight path is

an8.13:2.16.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

an8.13:2.18.pli: ‘kāmaṃ taco ca nhāru ca aṭṭhi ca avasissatu, sarīre upassussatu maṃsalohitaṃ; yaṃ taṃ purisathāmena purisavīriyena purisaparakkamena pattabbaṃ, na taṃ apāpuṇitvā vīriyassa saṇṭhānaṃ bhavissatī’ti.
an8.13:2.18.eng: ‘Gladly, let my skin, sinews, and bones remain! Let the blood and flesh waste away in my body! I will not stop trying until I have achieved what is possible by human strength, energy, and vigor.’

an8.13:2.19.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
an8.13:2.19.eng: A mendicant with these eight qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

an8.14:1.1.pli: “Aṭṭha ca, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅke desessāmi aṭṭha ca assadose, aṭṭha ca purisakhaḷuṅke aṭṭha ca purisadose.
an8.14:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you about eight wild colts and eight defects in horses, and about eight wild people and eight defects in people.

an8.14:1.2.pli: Taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
an8.14:1.2.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an8.14:1.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

an8.14:2.1.pli: “Katame ca, bhikkhave, aṭṭha assakhaḷuṅkā aṭṭha ca assadosā?
an8.14:2.1.eng: “And what, mendicants, are the eight wild colts and eight defects in horses?

an8.14:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā pacchato paṭikkamati, piṭṭhito rathaṃ pavatteti.
an8.14:2.2.eng: Firstly, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts back right up and spin the chariot behind them.

an8.14:2.3.eng: Some wild colts are like that.

an8.14:2.4.eng: This is the first defect of a horse.

an8.14:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā pacchā laṅghati, kubbaraṃ hanati, tidaṇḍaṃ bhañjati.
an8.14:3.1.eng: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts jump back, wreck the hub, and break the triple rod.

an8.14:3.2.eng: Some wild colts are like that.

an8.14:3.3.eng: This is the second defect of a horse.

an8.14:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā rathīsāya satthiṃ ussajjitvā rathīsaṃyeva ajjhomaddati.
an8.14:4.1.eng: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts shake the cart-pole off their thigh and trample it.

an8.14:4.2.eng: Some wild colts are like that.

an8.14:4.3.eng: This is the third defect of a horse.

an8.14:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā ummaggaṃ gaṇhati, ubbaṭumaṃ rathaṃ karoti.
an8.14:5.1.eng: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts take a wrong turn, sending the chariot off track.

an8.14:5.2.eng: Some wild colts are like that.

an8.14:5.3.eng: This is the fourth defect of a horse.

an8.14:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā laṅghati purimakāyaṃ paggaṇhati purime pāde.
an8.14:6.1.eng: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts rear up and strike out with their fore-legs.

an8.14:6.2.eng: Some wild colts are like that.

an8.14:6.3.eng: This is the fifth defect of a horse.

an8.14:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā anādiyitvā sārathiṃ anādiyitvā patodalaṭṭhiṃ dantehi mukhādhānaṃ vidhaṃsitvā yena kāmaṃ pakkamati.
an8.14:7.1.eng: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts ignore the trainer and the goad, spit out the bit, and go wherever they want.

an8.14:7.2.eng: Some wild colts are like that.

an8.14:7.3.eng: This is the sixth defect of a horse.

an8.14:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā neva abhikkamati no paṭikkamati tattheva khīlaṭṭhāyī ṭhito hoti.
an8.14:8.1.eng: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts don’t step forward or turn back but stand right there still as a post.

an8.14:8.2.eng: Some wild colts are like that.

an8.14:8.3.eng: This is the seventh defect of a horse.

an8.14:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, idhekacco assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā purime ca pāde saṃharitvā pacchime ca pāde saṃharitvā tattheva cattāro pāde abhinisīdati.
an8.14:9.1.eng: Furthermore, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, some wild colts tuck in their fore-legs and hind-legs, and sit right down on their four legs.

an8.14:9.2.eng: Some wild colts are like that.

an8.14:9.3.eng: This is the eighth defect of a horse.

an8.14:9.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭha assakhaḷuṅkā aṭṭha ca assadosā.
an8.14:9.4.eng: These are the eight wild colts and the eight defects in horses.

an8.14:10.1.pli: Katame ca, bhikkhave, aṭṭha purisakhaḷuṅkā aṭṭha ca purisadosā?
an8.14:10.1.eng: And what are the eight wild people and eight defects in people?

an8.14:10.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
an8.14:10.2.eng: Firstly, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.

an8.14:10.3.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno ‘na sarāmī’ti asatiyā nibbeṭheti.
an8.14:10.3.eng: But the accused mendicant evades it by saying they don’t remember.

an8.14:10.4.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā pacchato paṭikkamati, piṭṭhito rathaṃ vatteti;
an8.14:10.4.eng: I say that this individual is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, back right up and spin the chariot behind them.

an8.14:10.6.eng: Some wild people are like that.

an8.14:10.7.eng: This is the first defect of a person.

an8.14:11.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
an8.14:11.1.eng: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.

an8.14:11.2.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno codakaṃyeva paṭippharati:
an8.14:11.2.eng: But the accused mendicant objects to the accuser:

an8.14:11.3.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho tuyhaṃ bālassa abyattassa bhaṇitena.
an8.14:11.3.eng: ‘What has an incompetent fool like you got to say?

an8.14:11.4.eng: How on earth could you imagine you’ve got something worth saying!’

an8.14:11.5.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā pacchā laṅghati, kubbaraṃ hanati, tidaṇḍaṃ bhañjati;
an8.14:11.5.eng: I say that this individual is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, jump back, wreck the hub, and break the triple rod.

an8.14:11.7.eng: Some wild people are like that.

an8.14:11.8.eng: This is the second defect of a person.

an8.14:12.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
an8.14:12.1.eng: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.

an8.14:12.2.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno codakasseva paccāropeti:
an8.14:12.2.eng: But the accused mendicant retorts to the accuser:

an8.14:12.3.pli: ‘tvaṃ khosi itthannāmaṃ āpattiṃ āpanno, tvaṃ tāva paṭhamaṃ paṭikarohī’ti.
an8.14:12.3.eng: ‘Well, you’ve fallen into such-and-such an offense. You should deal with that first.’

an8.14:12.4.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā rathīsāya satthiṃ ussajjitvā rathīsaṃyeva ajjhomaddati;
an8.14:12.4.eng: I say that this individual is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, shake the cart-pole off their thigh and trample it.

an8.14:12.6.eng: Some wild people are like that.

an8.14:12.7.eng: This is the third defect of a person.

an8.14:13.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
an8.14:13.1.eng: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.

an8.14:13.2.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno aññenāññaṃ paṭicarati, bahiddhā kathaṃ apanāmeti, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
an8.14:13.2.eng: But the accused mendicant dodges the issue, distracts the discussion with irrelevant points, and displays annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

an8.14:13.3.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā ummaggaṃ gaṇhati, ubbaṭumaṃ rathaṃ karoti;
an8.14:13.3.eng: I say that this individual is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, take a wrong turn, sending the chariot off track.

an8.14:13.5.eng: Some wild people are like that.

an8.14:13.6.eng: This is the fourth defect of a person.

an8.14:14.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
an8.14:14.1.eng: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.

an8.14:14.2.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno saṅghamajjhe bāhuvikkhepaṃ karoti.
an8.14:14.2.eng: But the accused mendicant gesticulates while speaking in the middle of the Saṅgha.

an8.14:14.3.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā laṅghati, purimakāyaṃ paggaṇhati purime pāde;
an8.14:14.3.eng: I say that this individual is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, rear up and strike out with their fore-legs.

an8.14:14.5.eng: Some wild people are like that.

an8.14:14.6.eng: This is the fifth defect of a person.

an8.14:15.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
an8.14:15.1.eng: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.

an8.14:15.2.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno anādiyitvā saṅghaṃ anādiyitvā codakaṃ sāpattikova yena kāmaṃ pakkamati.
an8.14:15.2.eng: But the accused mendicant ignores the Saṅgha and the accusation and, though still guilty of the offense, they go wherever they want.

an8.14:15.3.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā anādiyitvā sārathiṃ anādiyitvā patodalaṭṭhiṃ dantehi mukhādhānaṃ vidhaṃsitvā yena kāmaṃ pakkamati;
an8.14:15.3.eng: I say that this individual is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, ignore the trainer and the goad, spit out the bit, and go wherever they want.

an8.14:15.5.eng: Some wild people are like that.

an8.14:15.6.eng: This is the sixth defect of a person.

an8.14:16.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
an8.14:16.1.eng: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.

an8.14:16.2.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno ‘nevāhaṃ āpannomhi, na panāhaṃ āpannomhī’ti so tuṇhībhāvena saṅghaṃ viheṭheti.
an8.14:16.2.eng: But the accused mendicant neither confesses to the offense nor denies it, but frustrates the Saṅgha by staying silent.

an8.14:16.3.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā neva abhikkamati no paṭikkamati tattheva khīlaṭṭhāyī ṭhito hoti;
an8.14:16.3.eng: I say that this individual is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, don’t step forward or turn back but stand right there still as a post.

an8.14:16.5.eng: Some wild people are like that.

an8.14:16.6.eng: This is the seventh defect of a person.

an8.14:17.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhū bhikkhuṃ āpattiyā codenti.
an8.14:17.1.eng: Furthermore, the mendicants accuse a mendicant of an offense.

an8.14:17.2.pli: So bhikkhu bhikkhūhi āpattiyā codiyamāno evamāha:
an8.14:17.2.eng: But the accused mendicant says this:

an8.14:17.3.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho tumhe āyasmanto atibāḷhaṃ mayi byāvaṭā yāva idānāhaṃ sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissāmī’ti.
an8.14:17.3.eng: ‘Why are you venerables making so much of an issue over me? Now I’ll resign the training and return to a lesser life.’

an8.14:17.4.eng: When they have resigned the training, they say:

an8.14:17.6.pli: Seyyathāpi so, bhikkhave, assakhaḷuṅko ‘pehī’ti vutto, viddho samāno codito sārathinā purime ca pāde saṃharitvā pacchime ca pāde saṃharitvā tattheva cattāro pāde abhinisīdati;
an8.14:17.6.eng: I say that this individual is comparable to the wild colts who, when the trainer says ‘giddyup!’ and spurs and goads them on, tuck in their fore-legs and hind-legs, and sit right down on their four legs.

an8.14:17.8.eng: Some wild people are like that.

an8.14:17.9.eng: This is the eighth defect of a person.

an8.14:17.10.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭha purisakhaḷuṅkā aṭṭha ca purisadosā”ti.
an8.14:17.10.eng: These are the eight wild people and eight defects in people.”

an8.148-627:1.26.eng: these eight things should be developed.”

an8.148-627:1.28.eng: The Book of the Eights is finished.

an8.15:1.3.eng: Not rehearsing is the stain of hymns.

an8.15:1.4.eng: Neglect is the stain of houses.

an8.15:1.5.eng: Laziness is the stain of beauty.

an8.15:1.9.pli: malā, bhikkhave, pāpakā akusalā dhammā asmiṃ loke paramhi ca;
an8.15:1.9.eng: Bad, unskillful qualities are a stain in this world and the next.

an8.15:1.10.pli: tato, bhikkhave, malā malataraṃ avijjā paramaṃ malaṃ.
an8.15:1.10.eng: Worse than any of these is ignorance, the worst stain of all.

an8.15:2.1.eng: Not rehearsing is the stain of hymns.

an8.15:2.2.eng: The stain of houses is neglect.

an8.15:2.3.eng: Laziness is the stain of beauty.

an8.15:3.4.eng: in this world and the next.

an8.15:3.5.eng: But a worse stain than these

an8.15:3.6.eng: is ignorance, the worst stain of all.”

an8.16:1.1.pli: “Aṭṭhahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu dūteyyaṃ gantumarahati.
an8.16:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with eight qualities is worthy of going on a mission.

an8.16:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sotā ca hoti, sāvetā ca, uggahetā ca, dhāretā ca, viññātā ca, viññāpetā ca, kusalo ca sahitāsahitassa, no ca kalahakārako—
an8.16:1.3.eng: It’s a mendicant who learns and educates others. They memorize and remember. They understand and help others understand. They’re skilled at knowing what’s on topic and what isn’t. And they don’t cause quarrels.

an8.16:1.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu dūteyyaṃ gantumarahati.
an8.16:1.4.eng: A mendicant with these eight qualities is worthy of going on a mission.

an8.16:1.5.pli: Aṭṭhahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato sāriputto dūteyyaṃ gantumarahati.
an8.16:1.5.eng: Having eight qualities Sāriputta is worthy of going on a mission.

an8.16:1.7.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sāriputto sotā ca hoti, sāvetā ca, uggahetā ca, dhāretā ca, viññātā ca, viññāpetā ca, kusalo ca sahitāsahitassa, no ca kalahakārako.
an8.16:1.7.eng: He learns and educates others. He memorizes and remembers. He understands and helps others understand. He’s skilled at knowing what’s on topic and what isn’t. And he doesn’t cause quarrels.

an8.16:1.8.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahi dhammehi samannāgato sāriputto dūteyyaṃ gantumarahatīti.
an8.16:1.8.eng: Having these eight qualities Sāriputta is worthy of going on a mission.

an8.17:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a woman catches a man using eight features.

an8.17:1.11.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahākārehi itthī purisaṃ bandhati.
an8.17:1.11.eng: A woman catches a man using these eight features.

an8.17:1.12.pli: Te, bhikkhave, sattā subaddhā, ye phassena baddhā”ti.
an8.17:1.12.eng: But those beings who are caught by touch are well and truly caught.”

an8.18:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a man catches a woman using eight features.

an8.18:1.11.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahākārehi puriso itthiṃ bandhati.
an8.18:1.11.eng: A man catches a woman using these eight features.

an8.18:1.12.pli: Te, bhikkhave, sattā subaddhā, ye phassena baddhā”ti.
an8.18:1.12.eng: But those beings who are caught by touch are well and truly caught.”
